description: Numerator of probability that there is no error when average of n numbers is computed, assuming errors of +1, -1 are possible and they each occur with p=1/4.
links: Robert M. Kozelka, Grade Point Averages and the Central Limit Theorem, American Mathematical Monthly. Nov. 1979 (86:9) pp. 773-7.
formula: a(n) = numerator(binomial(2*n-1/2, -1/2)).a(n) = numerator((4*n)!/(2^(4*n)*(2*n)!^2)) - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jul 06 2009a(n) = A001448(n)/A001316(n). - _Peter Luschny_, Mar 23 2014
example: For n=1, the binomial(2*n-1/2, -1/2) yields the term 3/8. The numerator of this term is 3, which is the second term of the sequence.
prog: (Sage)def A061548(n): return binomial(4*n,2*n)/2^sum(n.digits(2))[A061548(n) for n in (0..20)]  # _Peter Luschny_, Mar 23 2014
author: Leah Schmelzer (leah2002(AT)mit.edu), May 16 2001
extensions: More terms from Asher Auel (asher.auel(AT)reed.edu), May 20 2001
